author: Jessica T
title: Paul Pierce Theorizes Why NBA Players Get with White Women
text:
During a recent episode of his Truth After Dark podcast, former NBA star Paul Pierce raised eyebrows after making controversial remarks about why he believes many NBA players date white women.
Pierce's co-host, Azar Farideh, posed the question, prompting Pierce to respond: “Because they maybe appreciate more, and they apologize more,” a comment that drew laughter from those in the room. He went on to say that white women “don’t mind being held accountable.”
The discussion recalled a previous podcast moment when actor Columbus Short made similar comments during an interview with Farideh. At the time, Short said, “There is no respect of the man, the Black man, in that by a Black woman.” His remarks were widely criticized, prompting Short to issue a public apology.
“I realize that I seriously offended my Black women in a way that was not intended,” Short said. “That clip was taken out of context. I know that was clickbait.”
Pierce’s recent comments have already begun to generate conversation on social media, reigniting ongoing debates around race, relationships, and public responsibility among celebrities.
Source: YouTube

author: Raül Bruna
title: L’ONU denuncia greus abusos a Cisjordània | Raül Bruna | Barcelona | Política | El Punt Avui
text: Conflicte Bèl·lic al Pròxim Orient L’ONU denuncia greus abusos a Cisjordània Nacions Unides (ONU) va reclamar ahir a Israel que acabi amb els “assassinats il·legals i la violència dels colons contra la població palestina” als territoris ocupats. L’Oficina de Drets Humans de l’ONU va presentar un informe que denuncia greus abusos per part de les forces de seguretat i els colons israelians, entre els quals “detencions il·legals i maltractament de detinguts”. L’alt comissionat per als Drets Humans, Volker Türk, va alertar del “ràpid deteriorament de la situació dels drets humans a la Cisjordània” i va demanar a Israel que “aturi immediatament” l’ús de tàctiques i armament militar “en contextos d’aplicació de la llei”. “L’ús de força innecessària o desproporcionada i l’aplicació de restriccions de moviment àmplies, arbitràries i discriminatòries que afecten els palestins són extremadament preocupants”, va afegir Türk sobre les conclusions de l’informe. El document certifica que entre el 7 d’octubre i el 27 d’octubre han mort tres-cents palestins a Cisjordània, inclosa Jerusalem Est, dels quals setanta-nou eren nens. Segons l’alt comissionat, les violacions documentades ara repeteixen el patró d’altres denúncies durant la “llarga ocupació israeliana de Cisjordània”, però “la intensitat de la violència i la repressió actuals no s’havia vist en anys”. Israel va reaccionar a l’informe qualificant-lo de “bastant ridícul”, en paraules Tal Heinrich, portaveu de l’oficina del primer ministre. Heinrich va criticar que el document no té en compte les amenaces a les que s’exposen les seves forces de seguretat a l’hora de “mantenir aquest front tan tranquil com sigui possible”. Cisjordània ha viscut aquest 2023 l’any més violent en dues dècades, amb més de mig miler de palestins morts en xocs amb tropes i atacants israelians. Ahir mateix, un jove palestí va perdre la vida durant una operació de l’exèrcit a Ramal·là, on catorze persones més van resultar ferides al centre de la ciutat. De la part israeliana, aquest any han perdut la vida 41 persones, la majoria colons. author: Chuck Chiang; The Canadian Press
title: Warm weather wreaks havoc on some B.C. ski hills as lack of snow leaves trails barren
text: VANCOUVER — British Columbia's abnormally warm winter has left local ski resorts grappling with a lack of snow during the holiday tourism season, as resorts struggle to keep runs open. Fewer than half of Whistler Blackcomb's trails are open, while Vancouver's Mount Seymour is closed entirely while it waits for better conditions. Warmth related to the El Niño climate phenomenon this week has pushed temperatures to record highs in regions including Metro Vancouver, Greater Victoria, the Sunshine Coast and the Okanagan. In Whistler, 120 kilometres north of Vancouver, Environment Canada was reporting no snow on the ground on Christmas Day, compared to 40 centimetres last Christmas. On Thursday, the Whistler Blackcomb resort reported 117 of its 275 trails were open, as well as only 42 per cent of its terrain. Warm weather has hit Metro Vancouver's three main ski hills even harder, with Cypress and Grouse mountains operating only one or two runs each. Mount Seymour closed entirely on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, pending more snow. James Shalman, general manager at Apex Mountain Resort in the Okanagans, says resorts across the province are "definitely behind the 8-ball" because of the warm weather, with visitors lost during the holidays unlikely to return later in the season. "All resorts in B.C. are very reliant on the Christmas holidays as a significant portion of their financial picture for the season," Shalman said. "This is not something where you can make up what you're down during Christmas break. You won't make that up later in the season, even if we get amazing snowfall in January, February, March." Apex on Thursday had about a third of its roughly 79 runs open, a stark contrast from 2022 when every run was open in the first week of December thanks to heavy snowfalls. Shalman said Apex had significant snow-making capacity and used it to combat the lack of precipitation, but there were weeks this month where the temperatures were too warm to make snow. "I mean, we are essentially snow farmers," he says. "We're Mother Nature-dependent, and we just have to take what we get." At Cypress Mountain in West Vancouver, management warned skiers of "thin snow coverage" for what little of the hill was open. Several resorts have been offering discounted passes and tickets to entice skiers to visit. "Rain's the star of the show today," Cypress Mountain's update on Thursday said, noting that night skiing had been cancelled. Environment Canada meteorologist Brian Proctor said that in addition to El Niño, a ridge of high pressure had created a "blocking pattern" across much of North America. That was preventing the warm air generated by El Niño from passing over mountains and continuing inland. Proctor said it meant the warm air mass had lingered over B.C., unable to go east due to high pressure acting like "a wall." He said Environment Canada's long-term forecast called for more seasonal temperatures to return for the first week of January, bringing potential snowfall to higher elevations in the Interior. But Proctor said snowfall was less certain for coastal areas in coming weeks, adding that skiers and resorts should temper expectations. "We may see potential for some snowfall," Proctor says. "But really longer term it does look like an El Niño winter at this point in time, continuing and remaining fairly significant into the early spring." This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 29, 2023. Chuck Chiang, The Canadian Press

author: sina.com.cn
title: 如何破解漫天飘"雪"的飞絮烦恼？|杨童舒_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
转自：团结报
　　张维娜
　　民革党员
　　吉林省长春市经济技术开发区威海小学教师
　　每年3月下旬至5月上旬是杨柳飞絮的高发时段，我国一些城市总会迎来一场别样的“雪季”。漫天飞舞的杨柳飞絮如雪花般轻盈飘落，为城市增添了几分诗意，却也给市民生活带来了诸多不便。
　　杨树和柳树为雌雄异株植物，它们雌株的果实成熟后会裂开，释放出带有白色绒毛的种子。白色绒毛如同天然的降落伞，帮助种子寻找新的生长之地，乘风传播可达千米。这些带有白色绒毛的种子在空气中飘动并相互聚集，就形成了我们所看到的杨柳飞絮。杨柳飞絮是植物生长发育过程中的一种自然现象，是植物种子传播和繁衍后代的一种自然进化方式。
　　如今，杨柳飞絮也给人们带来了困扰——单棵成年杨柳年产絮量达1公斤，飞絮飘散时容易裹挟细菌、病毒等污染物，形成直径几十微米的过敏原，或成为传播疾病的媒介。每年飞絮高发季节对市民健康而言，无疑是一场严峻考验。据统计，因飞絮导致的过敏性鼻炎、哮喘等呼吸道疾病就诊量在飞絮高发季节会显著增加。
　　不少民众心存疑惑，飞絮给大家生活带来诸多困扰，为何不能将产生飞絮的树木“一砍了之”？这背后实则涉及生态平衡与城市绿化的复杂考量。杨柳作为北方城市绿化的主要树种，有着诸多无可替代的优势。它们生长速度快、成活率高、成本低廉、生态效益显著，若盲目砍伐杨柳，不仅会大幅增加绿化成本支出，还会严重破坏城市生态系统，导致生物多样性减少，进而引发土壤侵蚀、水源污染等一系列生态问题。所以，治理飞絮问题，要采取科学合理的方法，在保障市民健康的同时，维护好城市生态平衡。
　　为破解飞絮难题，不少城市积极探索实践。以吉林省长春市为例，自2017年起，便着手开展全市街路杨柳树飞絮专项治理工作。在城市景观更新过程中，长春逐步替换部分飞絮严重的杨柳雌株，种植不易产生飞絮的雄性杨柳，或移栽红枫等其他树种，从源头上减少飞絮的产生。同时，通过修剪雌株、高压枪冲刷、利用喷水车进行路面湿化作业等物理拦截方法，有效减少飞絮的扬飞。科研人员也在不懈努力，积极探索更高效的治理方法，如给雌树注射“避孕针”抑制花芽分化，通过调节杨柳的生理机能，实现对其繁殖周期的科学调控，以期在保障生态效益的同时，最大限度减少飞絮对市民生活的影响。经过几年的持续治理，长春市杨柳飞絮现象得到明显改善。
　　在飞絮高发季节，做好个人防护也至关重要，牢记“躲、捂、洗、吃、调”五字诀能有效减轻飞絮困扰。“躲”，即尽量避开10时至16时杨柳飞絮高发时段外出，可选择早晨、傍晚或雨后等飞絮较轻的时段出门；“捂”，外出时佩戴口罩、防护镜、纱巾等，进行有效物理遮挡；“洗”，回家后用清水及时清洗面部，使用洗鼻器或鼻腔喷雾清洗鼻腔，同时漱口；“吃”，多喝水，多食用水果、蔬菜等富含维生素C和维生素E的食物，以缓解过敏症状；“调”，易过敏人群可提前两周用药预防，调节身体状态，缓解飞絮带来的不适。

author: archyde
title: Meta Secretly Trained AI on Pirated LibGen Dataset, Court Documents Reveal
text:
In ⁤a high-stakes legal ​battle, ⁢Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is⁣ facing allegations of knowingly using pirated datasets⁢ to train its AI models. The controversy centers around the⁤ use of a ​dataset from‍ LibGen, a shadow library known for hosting copyrighted material without authorization. Plaintiffs in the case ⁢claim that Meta’s leadership, including CEO Mark​ Zuckerberg, was fully aware of the ‌dataset’s pirated nature. “Meta has treated the so-called ⁢‘public availability’ of shadow datasets as a get​ out of jail free card, notwithstanding that ‍internal Meta records show every⁤ relevant⁣ decision-maker at Meta, up to⁤ and including its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, knew LibGen was ‘a dataset we know to be⁤ pirated,’” the plaintiffs allege in a recent motion. The motion, originally filed in late 2024, seeks ‌to amend the complaint for⁤ a third time, adding new claims based on ‌evidence uncovered ⁤during the revelation process. Meta, however, has⁤ pushed back against these allegations, calling‍ the plaintiffs’ efforts an “eleventh-hour gambit based on a false and inflammatory premise.” The tech giant argues that it disclosed⁤ its ⁢use of the LibGen ‍dataset to ⁢the plaintiffs as⁤ early ‍as July 2024 and denies withholding crucial information. “Plaintiffs knew of Meta’s downloading and use of LibGen and other alleged ‘shadow libraries’ as at least mid-July 2024,” Meta’s lawyers stated in their opposition filing.
Despite Meta’s claims, ​the plaintiffs argue ​that the discovery process⁣ has ​revealed damning evidence. They ‌allege that Meta not ⁤onyl used pirated⁤ datasets but‌ also actively participated⁢ in distributing copyrighted material. ​“Meta, through a corporate representative who testified⁢ on November 20,‍ 2024, has now admitted‍ under oath to uploading (aka ‘seeding’)‍ pirated files containing⁣ Plaintiffs’ works on ‘torrent’ sites,” the motion ‍states. Seeding,a term used in peer-to-peer file sharing,refers to the act of sharing downloaded files⁤ with other ​users,further‍ perpetuating the distribution of ‌pirated content.
The legal drama has ⁢also drawn attention⁣ to Meta’s handling of sensitive documents.⁤ Judge ⁣Chhabria, overseeing the case, issued‌ a stern warning to the company regarding its ‍redaction practices. “If ‌Meta ⁤again submits an ‍unreasonably broad sealing ​request, all materials will simply be unsealed,”‍ he wrote. This statement underscores the court’s commitment to clarity, even⁤ as much of the discovery material‌ remains confidential.
As the⁢ case unfolds, it raises critical questions about the ethical use of data ⁣in AI development.‍ The plaintiffs’ allegations, if⁤ proven, could have far-reaching implications for Meta and the broader tech industry. For now, the ⁤legal battle continues, with both sides ⁢digging ⁤in ⁣for what promises to‍ be a protracted and contentious fight.
What specific policy recommendations⁤ stemming from your research ⁢have you found ⁤most impactful⁤ in influencing global climate action? Interview with Dr. ‍Evelyn Carter: Pioneering Climate Scientist and Advocate for Enduring​ Innovation
By Archys, Archyde News Editor
Archyde News : Good afternoon, Dr. Carter, and thank you for⁢ joining us today. Your work in climate science and sustainable innovation has been‌ groundbreaking. To start,⁢ could you tell ​our⁢ readers a little about your journey into⁤ this field and what ⁤inspired you to dedicate ⁣your ​career to addressing climate⁢ change?
Dr. Evelyn Carter: Thank you for ​having me.‍ My journey into ⁢climate science began⁤ during my undergraduate studies in environmental science. I grew up in a small coastal town,‍ and I ‌witnessed firsthand the effects of​ rising sea levels and increasingly severe ⁣storms.It was alarming to⁢ see how quickly the surroundings around me was changing. That personal⁤ connection to ‍the issue ⁣drove me to pursue a Ph.D. in climate ⁤science, where I focused on understanding the mechanisms of climate⁣ change ⁢and developing actionable solutions to mitigate its impact.
Archyde News : ⁤Your research has been instrumental in shaping ⁤global climate policies. What do you ​consider your‌ most critically important contribution to the ⁢field so far?
Dr. Carter: That’s a great question. I think one of the most impactful contributions has been my work‌ on developing predictive models that link climate change to specific economic and⁢ social outcomes. ⁢For example, our team created a model that ⁤predicts how rising temperatures will affect agricultural productivity in different‍ regions. This has‍ helped ‌policymakers prioritize‍ resources and develop targeted strategies⁢ to⁢ support vulnerable communities. Additionally, my advocacy for integrating renewable ⁣energy technologies into urban planning has gained traction in several cities worldwide, leading to more sustainable infrastructure projects.
Archyde News : Speaking of renewable energy, ther’s been a lot of debate about the ⁣feasibility‍ of transitioning ​entirely to renewable⁣ sources. What’s your take on this?
Dr. Carter: The transition to renewable energy is not only feasible⁤ but essential. ⁣The technology already exists—solar, wind, and ‍geothermal energy are becoming more efficient ​and cost-effective every year. The ⁢challenge lies⁤ in scaling thes solutions and ensuring they are accessible​ to ⁤all communities, not just those in developed ​nations. We also need to address the infrastructure gaps and invest ⁣in ​energy storage solutions to manage the intermittent nature of some renewable sources. it’s⁤ a complex process, but with the right policies and investments, we can achieve a sustainable energy future.
Archyde News : You’ve been a vocal​ advocate for interdisciplinary collaboration in tackling climate​ change. why do you believe this approach is so vital?
Dr.‌ Carter: Climate change is a ‍multifaceted ⁢issue that ‌transcends conventional academic and professional ⁣boundaries. It’s not just‍ a scientific problem—it’s an ‌economic,social,and political challenge ⁢as‌ well. by ⁢bringing together experts from‌ diverse fields—engineers, economists, sociologists,⁤ policymakers—we⁣ can develop⁢ holistic solutions that ⁣address the root causes of​ climate ⁤change‍ while also considering the human impact.‌ For instance, my recent ⁢collaboration with urban planners and‍ social‍ scientists has led to ⁢the advancement of climate-resilient housing designs that are both environmentally sustainable and affordable for low-income families.
Archyde ⁣ News : ⁤That’s fascinating. On a more personal note, what keeps you motivated in the face of⁤ such ‌a ​daunting global⁣ challenge?
Dr.​ Carter: It’s⁣ easy to feel overwhelmed ⁤by the scale of​ the problem, but I find ⁣motivation in the progress we’ve‌ made‍ and the passion of the next generation. Young activists, scientists, and entrepreneurs are⁢ bringing ⁤fresh perspectives and innovative ideas to the ‍table. ⁤Seeing their enthusiasm reminds‌ me that change is possible. I’m also inspired by the communities I’ve worked with—people who are directly affected ⁣by climate change⁤ but are taking ‍proactive steps ⁤to ⁣adapt and thrive.Their resilience gives me hope.
Archyde News : what ⁢message would you like to leave with our readers who might potentially be wondering how they can contribute to the fight ‍against climate change?
Dr. Carter: Every⁢ action counts. Whether it’s reducing your carbon footprint, supporting sustainable businesses, or advocating for stronger climate policies, your‌ choices matter. Educate yourself about the issues and‍ engage in conversations with⁣ others.⁢ Collective action is powerful, ⁤and together, ‍we can drive the systemic changes needed to protect our planet for future generations.
Archyde News : Thank you,​ Dr. Carter, for sharing your insights​ and for your tireless‌ work in this ‍critical⁢ field. ‍We look forward‌ to seeing what you accomplish next.
Dr. carter: Thank‍ you. It’s been ‌a pleasure.

title: Omni Brands auf Wachstumskurs: E-Commerce-Unternehmen sucht 10 neue Mitarbeiter für den Standort Eschborn
text:
Omni Brands auf Wachstumskurs: E-Commerce-Unternehmen sucht 10 neue Mitarbeiter für den Standort Eschborn
Eschborn (ots) - Die Omni Brands GmbH mit Sitz in Eschborn wächst weiter und sucht zum nächstmöglichen Zeitpunkt zehn neue Mitarbeiter – darunter in den Bereichen Grafikdesign, Social Media, Performance-Marketing sowie kaufmännische und organisatorische Aufgaben.
Das Team der Omni Brands GmbH mit den Geschäftsführern Florian Salzer und David Jaschenkow betreibt eine der führenden E-Commerce-Marken Europas für personalisierte Geschenkartikel. Die Marke bietet eine breite Auswahl an Produkten wie Leinwände, Poster und Decken, die Kunden einfach online personalisieren können, sodass jedes Produkt zu einem einzigartigen Geschenk wird. Die Produkte werden über eigene Online-Shops vertrieben und auf Plattformen wie Instagram und TikTok erfolgreich vermarktet.
Bereits im ersten Geschäftsjahr erzielte das Unternehmen einen Umsatz von zehn Millionen Euro – ein klares Zeichen dafür, wie tragfähig und zukunftsorientiert die E-Commerce-Branche ist. Auf dieser Basis gelingt es Omni Brands, planvoll zu wachsen und seine Marke nachhaltig auf dem europäischen Markt zu etablieren.
"Wir wollen Europas führender Anbieter für personalisierte Produkte werden“, erklärt Geschäftsführer Florian Salzer. „Dafür brauchen wir Menschen, die gerne in einem strukturierten Arbeitsumfeld Verantwortung übernehmen.“
Wer bei Omni Brands arbeitet, den erwartet eine strukturierte Einarbeitung, ein attraktives Gehalt und echte Karriereperspektiven. Neue Mitarbeiter profitieren von einem sicheren Arbeitsplatz mit langfristiger Perspektive, denn jede Einstellung ist auf eine unbefristete Übernahme ausgerichtet. Ein klar strukturiertes Arbeitsumfeld mit definierten Prozessen und Abläufen sorgt zudem für Orientierung und Sicherheit im Arbeitsalltag. Das Büro in Eschborn bietet eine moderne, gut ausgestattete Arbeitsumgebung – mit klimatisierten Räumen, ergonomischen Arbeitsplätzen und aktueller Technik.
Auch Quereinsteiger finden bei Omni Brands passende Einstiegsmöglichkeiten – besonders im Bereich Marketing. Neue Teammitglieder profitieren von einer digitalen Schulungsplattform, die exklusives Fachwissen bereitstellt und alle wichtigen Abläufe Schritt für Schritt erklärt. So können auch Berufs- und Quereinsteiger innerhalb kürzester Zeit eingearbeitet werden und frühzeitig Verantwortung in ihrem Aufgabenbereich übernehmen.
Interessierte Bewerber können sich unter karriere.omnibrands.de und https://www.omnibrands.de/ bewerben!

title: Typhoon Kong-rey bashes Taiwan, the largest storm to hit island since 1996
text: We show you our most important and recent visitors news details Typhoon Kong-rey bashes Taiwan, the largest storm to hit island since 1996 in the following article Hind Al Soulia - Riyadh - TAIPEI — Heavy rains and high winds lashed Taiwan on Thursday as the largest storm to hit the island in nearly three decades made landfall along its southeast coast, killing at least one person and injuring dozens. Typhoon Kong-rey packed winds approaching 200 kilometers per hour (125 mph), equivalent to a Category 3 Atlantic hurricane, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), as it made landfall in Taitung county on Thursday afternoon. Kong-rey’s radius of maximum wind – how far the strongest winds are from its center – measured 320 kilometers (nearly 200 miles) on Wednesday evening, making it the largest storm to hit Taiwan since Typhoon Herb in 1996, said Chang Chun-yao, a forecaster with the island’s Central Weather Administration (CWA). At least two were killed and more than 500 storm-related injuries were reported, according to Taiwan’s Central Emergency Operations Center (CEOC) A 56-year-old woman was killed by a falling tree while traveling by car in the central county of Nantou, and a 48-year-old man died on Thursday night after he was hit by an electric pole that fell during the typhoon in Taipei. Ahead of the powerful storm, local authorities ordered offices and schools to temporarily close, while Taiwan suspended trading on its stock market. Taiwan generally has a strong track record of responding to major typhoons, though remote villages in more mountainous regions can be particularly vulnerable to landslides. Taiwan’s military put more than 34,000 soldiers on standby to assist with rescue efforts and over 8,600 people had been evacuated from high-risk areas on Wednesday, the CEOC said. More than 500 flights, including 300 international journeys, have been canceled, and all ferry services to Taiwan’s outlying islands have been suspended, according to Taiwan’s Civil Aviation Administration. High-speed rail services are operating at limited capacity, according to the rail operator, while the Taipei metro said it had suspended services on open-air sections. Images from Taiwan’s official Central News Agency and social media showed ferocious waves slamming into the coast of Taitung county, while parts of neighboring Hualien county were submerged in floodwaters. Toppled road signs and traffic lights were also seen across Taiwan, social media images showed. Kong-rey rapidly intensified to reach super typhoon strength on Wednesday as it barreled toward Taiwan after bashing the Philippines. Though the storm weakened slightly ahead of making direct landfall in Taiwan, has unleashed intense downpours, bringing flash flooding, storm surges and the risk of landslides. The heaviest rainfall was expected across eastern Taiwan. Taiwan’s weather agency on Thursday issued an “extremely torrential” rainfall warning, its highest level, for parts of Yilan, Hualien, Taichung and Taitung counties along the east coast. The rest of eastern Taiwan and parts of the island’s north, including Taipei, are under a “torrential” rainfall warning, the second-highest level. Additional rainfall of over half a meter (20 inches) is still possible across parts of eastern Taiwan, which could lead to flash flooding and landslides, according to the CWA. Warmer oceans from the human-caused climate crisis are leading storms to intensify more rapidly, according to scientists. Kong-rey is the third typhoon to make landfall on Taiwan this year, after Krathon and Gaemi. Earlier this month, Typhoon Krathon killed four people as it brought particularly heavy rains to the south of the island. In recent days, northern parts of the Philippines’ main island of Luzon have been lashed by the outer bands of Kong-rey, known locally as Leon, as authorities ordered evacuations and warned of its impacts after already seeing devastation last week from Tropical Storm Trami, known as Kristine, which killed at least 130 people. After moving into the northern Taiwan Strait, the storm is forecast to head into the East China Sea and toward Japan. — CNN These were the details of the news Typhoon Kong-rey bashes Taiwan, the largest storm to hit island since 1996 for this day. author: Linda Carroll
title: Shingles vaccine may protect against dementia, new study suggests
text:
New research suggests that getting vaccinated against shingles might offer protection against dementia.
Shingles is a a painful and debilitating condition that occurrs in people who have had chickenpox, when the varicella zoster virus — which causes both conditions — reactivates in the body.
The new research, published Wednesday in Nature, analysed data from more than 280,000 older adults in Wales and found people who received the original shingles live virus vaccine were 20 per cent less likely to develop dementia of any type than those who were not vaccinated.
Know the news with the 7NEWS app: Download today
Previous research has found an association between the Shingrix shingles vaccine, which replaced the live virus version in 2020, and a lower risk of dementia, especially in women.
But that link wasn’t considered as strong because that study design couldn’t account for potential differences between those who were vaccinated and those who were not, such as the possibility that the vaccinated people might have been healthier overall.
Shingrix, which targets a tiny bit of viral DNA, turned out to have a longer lasting effect than the original vaccine.
The new study was possible because of an unusual public health policy in Wales that provided a “natural experiment” to explore the potential impact of the vaccine on dementia risk.
The rollout of the vaccine in Wales on September 1, 2013, was offered to people who were 79 on that date, but not to people who had turned 80.
That allowed the German and Stanford University researchers to compare two groups of people with similar health characteristics who differed only by one week in age.
This meant the two groups were essentially the same except the vaccine was available to the younger population but not the older, Stanford University assistant professor of medicine, and a senior author of the study, Dr Pascal Geldsetzer said.
What’s exciting about the study is that it’s essentially like a randomised controlled trial, considered the gold standard in research, he said.
‘A pretty strong effect’
The way the original vaccine was rolled out in Wales provided a unique opportunity, Columbia University Aging Centre professor of epidemiology Allison Aiello said.
“It’s like having a control group compared to a treated group,” Aiello, who was not associated with the new research, said.
“What’s interesting is the finding of 20 per cent protection. That is a pretty strong effect, which does fit with other research suggesting that herpes viruses might have an influence on dementia.”
Scientists don’t know exactly how the chickenpox virus raises the risk of dementia.
It’s been shown that reactivation of the virus can lead to the accumulation of aberrant proteins associated with Alzheimer’s, for example, Geldsetzer said.
It’s also possible that the virus might spark a reactivation of herpes simplex, which earlier research has linked to dementia.
Herpes viruses never completely go away but instead lurk in the body until the immune system weakens.
Ageing leads to a natural weakening of the immune system that can allow the virus to resurface as shingles, a nasty side effect of chickenpox.
The age effect is why the shingles vaccine has been offered only to people age 50 and older in the US. It’s given as two doses, two to six months apart.
Herpes viruses, including oral and genital herpes simplex, appear to have the ability to get into the central nervous system, experts said.
In fact, a 2024 study found among 70-year-olds without dementia at the outset, older adults with a herpes simplex diagnosis were more than twice as likely as uninfected people to develop dementia over a 15-year follow-up.
Herpes simplex can wreak havoc if it passes through the blood-brain barrier. It can cause inflammation of both the meninges (meningitis) and the brain (encephalitis). Both can be fatal.
Not the first study, but limitations exist
Bolstering the case for the shingles vaccine protecting against dementia were the findings from a study published in Nature Medicine in 2024 that analysed medical records from more than 100,000 patients.
That analysis suggested the newer shingles vaccine was associated with even better protection against dementia.
In that study, researchers also investigated whether two other vaccines — for influenza and tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis — had any impact on the risk for dementia. They did not.
Dr Aarati Didwania, a professor of medicine and medical education at Northwestern University’s Feinberg School of Medicine in Chicago, said that the most important take-home message from the Stanford study is that getting vaccinated might lower the risk for dementia, said
Exactly how the vaccines might protect against dementia isn’t clear, Didwania said. “But it’s an intriguing question,” she added. “Is it by decreasing inflammation or preventing the virus from reactivating?”
There’s certainly a good reason for getting vaccinated, Didwania said.
“Shingles is a terrible, painful and debilitating condition that can lead to horrendous long-term pain,” she said.
There are limitations to the new study.
While it indicates the benefit of the vaccine in a real-world setting, it’s not the same as a randomised controlled trial, Vanderbilt University Medical Centre professor of infectious diseases Dr William Schaffner said.
But it wouldn’t be ethical to randomly assign people to get the vaccine or not, he said.
“It’s provocative, interesting and exciting,” he said of the research.
It’s possible that the US Food and Drug Administration could review research linking shingles vaccines to a lower risk of dementia and allow the drug company to add that indication to the label, Schaffner said.
Even if that doesn’t happen, doctors can use the study findings to convince patients to choose to be vaccinated.
“Clearly there are lots of people 50 and over who have not received the vaccine,” he said.
“If you say there are some data that suggest the vaccine might prevent some cases of dementia, people might be persuaded.”
